001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.oklab;
002
003import com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.Color;
004import com.badlogic.gdx.math.MathUtils;
005import com.badlogic.gdx.utils.NumberUtils;
006import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.FloatColors;
007import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.Shaders;
008import com.github.tommyettinger.colorful.TrigTools;
009
010import java.io.UnsupportedEncodingException;
011import java.util.Random;
012
013/**
014 * Contains code for manipulating colors as {@code int} and packed {@code float} values in the Oklab color space.
015 * Oklab is a very new color space that builds on the same foundation as IPT, but seems to be better-calibrated for
016 * uniform lightness and colorfulness, instead of just the emphasis on uniform hue that IPT has. Relative to IPT, Oklab
017 * has a noticeably smaller range in chromatic channels (IPT's protan and tritan can range past 0.8 or as low as 0.35,
018 * but the similar A and B channels in Oklab don't stray past about 0.65 at the upper end, if that), but it does this so
019 * the difference between two Oklab colors is just the Euclidean distance between their components. A slight difference
020 * between Oklab and IPT here is that IPT shrinks the chromatic channels to store their -1 to 1 range in a color float's
021 * 0 to 1 range, then offsets the shrunken range from -0.5 to 0.5, to 0 to 1; Oklab does not need to shrink the range,
022 * and only offsets it in the same way (both just add 0.5).
023 * <br>
024 * Here's <a href="https://bottosson.github.io/posts/oklab/">Bj√∂rn Ottosson's original post introducing Oklab</a>.
025 * So far, <a href="https://raphlinus.github.io/color/2021/01/18/oklab-critique.html">it stood up to analysis by Raph
026 * Levien</a>, and seems to be gaining fans quickly.
027 */
028public class ColorTools {
029        /**
030         * Gets a packed float representation of a color given as 4 float components, here, L (luminance or lightness), A
031         * (a chromatic component ranging from greenish to reddish, called protan in IPT), B (a chromatic component ranging
032         * from bluish to yellowish, called tritan in IPT), and alpha (or opacity). As long as you use a batch with
033         * {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} as its shader, colors passed with
034         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)} will be interpreted as Oklab. L should be
035         * between 0 and 1, inclusive, with 0 used for very dark colors (almost only black), and 1 used for very light
036         * colors (almost only white). A and B range from 0.0 to 1.0, with grayscale results when both are about 0.5.
037         * There's some aesthetic value in changing just one chroma value. When A is high and B is low, the color is more
038         * purple/magenta, when both are low it is more bluish, when B is high and A is low, the color tends to be greenish,
039         * and when both are high it tends to be orange. When A and B are both near 0.5f, the color is closer to gray.
040         * Alpha is the multiplicative opacity of the color, and acts like RGBA's alpha.
041         * <br>
042         * This method bit-masks the resulting color's byte values, so any values can technically be given to this as
043         * L, A, and B, but they will only be reversible from the returned float color to the original L,
044         * A, and B values if the original values were in the range that {@link #channelL(float)}, {@link #channelA(float)},
045         * and {@link #channelB(float)} return. You can use {@link #inGamut(float, float, float)} to check if a given set of
046         * L, A, and B values is in-gamut, that is, it can be converted to and from an RGB color without going out of the
047         * valid range. If you just want to enforce that a color is in-gamut, you can use
048         * {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}, which takes the same parameters this method does, or
049         * {@link #limitToGamut(float)} if you already have a packed float color that could be out-of-gamut.
050         *
051         * @param l     0f to 1f, lightness or L component of Oklab, with 0.5f meaning "no change" and 1f brightening
052         * @param a     0f to 1f, protan or A component of Oklab, with 1f more orange, red, or magenta
053         * @param b     0f to 1f, tritan or B component of Oklab, with 1f more green, yellow, or red
054         * @param alpha 0f to 1f, 0f makes the color transparent and 1f makes it opaque
055         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
056         */
057        public static float oklab(float l, float a, float b, float alpha) {
058                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (alpha * 255) << 24 & 0xFE000000) | ((int) (b * 255) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
059                                | ((int) (a * 255) << 8 & 0xFF00) | ((int) (l * 255) & 0xFF));
060        }
061
062
063        /**
064         * An approximation of the cube-root function for float inputs and outputs.
065         * This can be about twice as fast as {@link Math#cbrt(double)}. This
066         * version does not tolerate negative inputs, because in the narrow use
067         * case it has in this class, it never is given negative inputs.
068         * <br>
069         * Has very low relative error (less than 1E-9) when inputs are uniformly
070         * distributed between 0 and 512, and absolute mean error of less than
071         * 1E-6 in the same scenario. Uses a bit-twiddling method similar to one
072         * presented in Hacker's Delight and also used in early 3D graphics (see
073         * https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fast_inverse_square_root for more, but
074         * this code approximates cbrt(x) and not 1/sqrt(x)). This specific code
075         * was originally by Marc B. Reynolds, posted in his "Stand-alone-junk"
076         * repo: https://github.com/Marc-B-Reynolds/Stand-alone-junk/blob/master/src/Posts/ballcube.c#L182-L197 .
077         * It's worth noting that while hardware instructions for finding the
078         * square root of a float have gotten extremely fast, the same is not
079         * true for the cube root (which has to allow negative inputs), so while
080         * the bit-twiddling inverse square root is no longer a beneficial
081         * optimization on current hardware, this does seem to help.
082         * <br>
083         * This is used when converting from RGB to Oklab, as an intermediate step.
084         * @param x any non-negative finite float to find the cube root of
085         * @return the cube root of x, approximated
086         */
087        private static float cbrtPositive(float x) {
088                int ix = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(x);
089                final float x0 = x;
090                ix = (ix>>>2) + (ix>>>4);
091                ix += (ix>>>4);
092                ix += (ix>>>8) + 0x2A5137A0;
093                x  = NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(ix);
094                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
095                x  = 0.33333334f*(2f * x + x0/(x*x));
096                return x;
097        }
098
099        /**
100         * Used when converting from Oklab to RGB, as an intermediate step.
101         * Really just {@code x * x * x}.
102         * @param x one of the LMS Prime channels to be converted to LMS
103         * @return an LMS channel value, which can be converted to RGB
104         */
105        private static float cube(final float x) {
106                return x * x * x;
107        }
108
109        /**
110         * Used when given non-linear sRGB inputs to make them linear, approximating with gamma 2.0.
111         * Really just {@code component * component}.
112         * @param component any non-linear channel of a color, to be made linear
113         * @return a linear version of component
114         */
115        private static float forwardGamma(final float component) {
116                return component * component;
117        }
118
119        /**
120         * Used to return from a linear, gamma-corrected input to an sRGB, non-linear output, using gamma 2.0.
121         * Really just a float version of the square root of component.
122         * @param component a linear channel of a color, to be made non-linear
123         * @return a non-linear version of component
124         */
125        private static float reverseGamma(final float component) {
126                return (float)Math.sqrt(component);
127        }
128
129        /**
130         * Changes the curve of a requested L value so that it matches the internally-used curve. This takes a curve with a
131         * very-dark area similar to sRGB (a very small one), and makes it significantly larger. This is typically used on
132         * "to Oklab" conversions.
133         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
134         * @return an adjusted L value that can be used internally
135         */
136        public static float forwardLight(final float L) {
137                return (L - 1.004f) / (1f - L * 0.4285714f) + 1.004f;
138//              return (L - 1f) / (1f - L * 0.4285714f) + 1f;
139        }
140
141        /**
142         * Changes the curve of the internally-used lightness when it is output to another format. This makes the very-dark
143         * area smaller, matching (kind-of) the curve that the standard sRGB lightness uses. This is typically used on "from
144         * Oklab" conversions.
145         * @param L lightness, from 0 to 1 inclusive
146         * @return an adjusted L value that can be fed into a conversion to RGBA or something similar
147         */
148        public static float reverseLight(final float L) {
149                return (L - 0.993f) / (1f + L * 0.75f) + 0.993f;
150//              return (L - 1f) / (1f + L * 0.75f) + 1f;
151        }
152
153        /**
154         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)} to an RGBA8888 int.
155         * This format of int can be used with Pixmap and in some other places in libGDX.
156         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
157         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
158         */
159        public static int toRGBA8888(final float packed)
160        {
161                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
162                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
163                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
164                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
165                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
166                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
167                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
168                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
169                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
170                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
171                return r << 24 | g << 16 | b << 8 | (decoded & 0xfe000000) >>> 24 | decoded >>> 31;
172        }
173
174        /**
175         * Converts a packed float color in the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
176         * to a packed float in RGBA format.
177         * This format of float can be used with the standard SpriteBatch and in some other places in libGDX.
178         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
179         * @return a packed float color as RGBA
180         */
181        public static float toRGBA(final float packed)
182        {
183                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
184                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
185                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
186                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
187                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
188                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
189                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
190                final int r = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
191                final int g = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
192                final int b = (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
193                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(r | g << 8 | b << 16 | (decoded & 0xfe000000));
194        }
195
196        /**
197         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
198         * into an RGBA8888 Color as used by libGDX (called {@code editing}).
199         * @param editing a libGDX color that will be filled in-place with an RGBA conversion of {@code packed}
200         * @param packed a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
201         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
202         */
203        public static Color toColor(Color editing, final float packed)
204        {
205                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
206                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
207                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
208                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
209                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
210                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
211                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
212                editing.r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
213                editing.g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
214                editing.b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
215                editing.a = (decoded >>> 25) * 0x1.020408p-7f; // this is 1/127 as a float
216                return editing.clamp();
217        }
218
219        /**
220         * Writes an Oklab-format packed float color (the format produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)})
221         * into an Oklab-format Color called {@code editing}. This is mostly useful if the rest of your application expects
222         * colors in Oklab format, such as because you use {@link Shaders#fragmentShaderOklab} or {@link ColorfulBatch}.
223         * <br>
224         * Internally, this simply calls {@link Color#abgr8888ToColor(Color, float)} and returns the edited Color.
225         * @param editing a libGDX Color that will be filled in-place with the color {@code oklab}, unchanged from its color space
226         * @param oklab a packed float color, as produced by {@link ColorTools#oklab(float, float, float, float)}
227         * @return an RGBA8888 int color
228         */
229        public static Color toOklabColor(Color editing, final float oklab){
230                Color.abgr8888ToColor(editing, oklab);
231                return editing;
232        }
233
234        /**
235         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 int and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
236         * @param rgba an int with the channels (in order) red, green, blue, alpha; should have 8 bits per channel
237         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
238         */
239        public static float fromRGBA8888(final int rgba) {
240                final float r = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 24) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
241                final float g = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
242                final float b = forwardGamma((rgba >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
243
244                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
245                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
246                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
247
248                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
249                                      Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
250                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
251                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
252                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
253                                                | (rgba & 0xFE) << 24);
254        }
255
256        /**
257         * Takes a color encoded as an RGBA8888 packed float and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
258         * @param packed a packed float in RGBA8888 format, with A in the MSB and R in the LSB
259         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
260         */
261        public static float fromRGBA(final float packed) {
262                final int abgr = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
263                final float r = forwardGamma((abgr & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
264                final float g = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 8 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
265                final float b = forwardGamma((abgr >>> 16 & 0xFF) * 0x1.010101010101p-8f);
266                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
267                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
268                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
269                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
270                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
271                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
272                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
273                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
274                                                | (abgr & 0xFE000000));
275        }
276
277        // original multipliers for LMS when obtaining the non-shrunken A and B values:
278        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
279        //+1.9779984951 -2.4285922050 +0.4505937099
280        //+0.0259040371 +0.7827717662 -0.8086757660
281
282        // shrunken multipliers:
283        //+0.2104542553 +0.7936177850 -0.0040720468
284        //+0.9889992500 -1.2142961000 +0.2252968500
285        //+0.0129520185 +0.3913858800 -0.4043378800
286
287        /**
288         * Takes a libGDX Color that uses RGBA8888 channels and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
289         * @param color a libGDX RGBA8888 Color
290         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
291         */
292        public static float fromColor(final Color color) {
293                final float r = forwardGamma(color.r);
294                final float g = forwardGamma(color.g);
295                final float b = forwardGamma(color.b);
296                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
297                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
298                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
299                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
300                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
301                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
302                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
303                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
304                                                | ((int)(color.a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
305        }
306
307        /**
308         * Takes RGBA components from 0.0 to 1.0 each and converts to a packed float in the Oklab format this uses.
309         * @param r red, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
310         * @param g green, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
311         * @param b blue, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
312         * @param a alpha, from 0.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive)
313         * @return a packed float as Oklab, which this class can use
314         */
315        public static float fromRGBA(float r, float g, float b, final float a) {
316                r = forwardGamma(r);
317                g = forwardGamma(g);
318                b = forwardGamma(b);
319                final float l = cbrtPositive(0.4121656120f * r + 0.5362752080f * g + 0.0514575653f * b);
320                final float m = cbrtPositive(0.2118591070f * r + 0.6807189584f * g + 0.1074065790f * b);
321                final float s = cbrtPositive(0.0883097947f * r + 0.2818474174f * g + 0.6302613616f * b);
322                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
323                                          Math.min(Math.max((int)(forwardLight
324                                                                                  (0.2104542553f * l + 0.7936177850f * m - 0.0040720468f * s) * 255.999f         ), 0), 255)
325                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((1.9779984951f * l - 2.4285922050f * m + 0.4505937099f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 8
326                                                | Math.min(Math.max((int)((0.0259040371f * l + 0.7827717662f * m - 0.8086757660f * s) * 127.999f + 127.5f), 0), 255) << 16
327                                                | ((int)(a * 255f) << 24 & 0xFE000000));
328        }
329
330        /**
331         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
332         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
333         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
334         */
335        public static int redInt(final float encoded)
336        {
337                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
338                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
339                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
340                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
341                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
342                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
343                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
344                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
345        }
346
347        /**
348         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
349         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
350         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
351         */
352        public static int greenInt(final float encoded)
353        {
354                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
355                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
356                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
357                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
358                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
359                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
360                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
361                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
362        }
363
364        /**
365         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as an int ranging from 0 to 255, inclusive.
366         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
367         * @return an int from 0 to 255, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
368         */
369        public static int blueInt(final float encoded)
370        {
371                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
372                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
373                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
374                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
375                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
376                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
377                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
378                return (int)(reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f)) * 255.999f);
379        }
380
381        /**
382         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as an even int ranging from 0 to 254, inclusive. Because
383         * of how alpha is stored in libGDX, no odd-number values are possible for alpha.
384         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
385         * @return an even int from 0 to 254, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
386         */
387        public static int alphaInt(final float encoded)
388        {
389                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24;
390        }
391
392        /**
393         * Gets the red channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
394         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
395         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the red channel value of the given encoded color
396         */
397        public static float red(final float encoded)
398        {
399                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
400                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
401                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
402                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
403                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
404                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
405                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
406                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
407        }
408
409        /**
410         * Gets the green channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
411         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
412         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the green channel value of the given encoded color
413         */
414        public static float green(final float encoded)
415        {
416                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
417                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
418                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
419                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
420                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
421                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
422                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
423                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
424        }
425
426        /**
427         * Gets the blue channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
428         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
429         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the blue channel value of the given encoded color
430         */
431        public static float blue(final float encoded)
432        {
433                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
434                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
435                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
436                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
437                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
438                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
439                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
440                return reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
441        }
442
443        /**
444         * Gets the alpha channel value of the given encoded color, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive.
445         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
446         * @return a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive, representing the alpha channel value of the given encoded color
447         */
448        public static float alpha(final float encoded)
449        {
450                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xfe000000) >>> 24) * 0x1.020408p-8f;
451        }
452
453        /**
454         * Gets the "chroma" or "colorfulness" of a given Oklab color. Chroma is similar to saturation in that grayscale
455         * values have 0 saturation and 0 chroma, while brighter colors have high saturation and chroma. The difference is
456         * that colors that are perceptually more-colorful have higher chroma than colors that are perceptually
457         * less-colorful, regardless of hue, whereas saturation changes its meaning depending on the hue and lightness. That
458         * is, the most saturated color for a given hue and lightness always has a saturation of 1, but if that color
459         * isn't perceptually very colorful (as is the case for very dark and very light colors), it will have a chroma that
460         * is much lower than the maximum. The result of this method can't be negative, grayscale values have very close to
461         * 0 chroma, and the most colorful values (all very close to magenta) should have 0.31613f chroma.
462         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
463         * @return a float between 0.0f and 0.31613f that represents how colorful the given value is
464         */
465        public static float chroma(final float encoded) {
466                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
467                final float a = ((decoded >>> 7 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF)  * 0x1p-8f;
468                final float b = ((decoded >>> 15 & 0x1FE) - 0xFF) * 0x1p-8f;
469                return (float) Math.sqrt(a * a + b * b);
470        }
471
472        /**
473         * Given a hue and lightness, this gets the (approximate) maximum chroma possible for that hue-lightness
474         * combination. This is useful to know the bounds of {@link #chroma(float)}. This should be no greater
475         * than 0.31613f .
476         * @param hue the hue, typically between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
477         * @param lightness the lightness, clamped between 0.0f and 1.0f, to look up
478         * @return the maximum possible chroma for the given hue and lightness, between 0.0f and 0.31613f
479         */
480        public static float chromaLimit(final float hue, final float lightness){
481                final int idx = (int) (Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f) * 255.999f) << 8
482                                | (int) (256f * (hue - MathUtils.floor(hue)));
483                return (GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f) * 0x1p-8f;
484        }
485
486        /**
487         * Gets a color as an Oklab packed float given floats representing hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity.
488         * All parameters should normally be between 0 and 1 inclusive, though any hue is tolerated (precision loss may
489         * affect the color if the hue is too large). A hue of 0 is red, progressively higher hue values go to orange,
490         * yellow, green, blue, and purple before wrapping around to red as it approaches 1. A saturation of 0 is grayscale,
491         * a saturation of 1 is brightly colored, and values close to 1 will usually appear more distinct than values close
492         * to 0, especially if the hue is different. A lightness of 0.001f or less is always black (also using a shortcut if
493         * this is the case, respecting opacity), while a lightness of 1f is white. Very bright colors are mostly in a band
494         * of high-saturation where lightness is 0.5f.
495         * <br>
496         * This method considers its hue, saturation, and lightness parameters as the HSL color space does. You may instead
497         * want the method {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)}, which treats lightness exactly as Oklab does,
498         * and handles hue and saturation with the Oklab color solid (which is shaped oddly) instead of the HSL color solid
499         * (which is a bicone, with a wide cone pointing up attached at the base to another wide cone pointing down).
500         * Using oklabByHSL() should be faster in many cases, and the lightness handling alone may be a reason to use it.
501         * There is also {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which may be preferable if you want a specific
502         * amount of chroma (colorful-ness) and no greater.
503         *
504         * @param hue        0f to 1f, color wheel position
505         * @param saturation 0f to 1f, 0f is grayscale and 1f is brightly colored
506         * @param lightness  0f to 1f, 0f is black and 1f is white
507         * @param opacity    0f to 1f, 0f is fully transparent and 1f is opaque
508         * @return a float encoding a color with the given properties
509         */
510        public static float floatGetHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float opacity) {
511                if (lightness <= 0.001f) {
512                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x7F7F00);
513                } else {
514                        return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue, saturation, lightness, opacity));
515                }
516        }
517
518        /**
519         * Gets the saturation of the given encoded color as HSL would calculate it, as a float ranging from 0.0f to 1.0f,
520         * inclusive. This is different from {@link #chroma(float)}; see that method's documentation for details. It is also
521         * different from {@link #oklabSaturation(float)}, which gets the saturation as Oklab understands it rather than how
522         * HSL understands it.
523         *
524         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
525         * @return the saturation of the color from 0.0 (a grayscale color; inclusive) to 1.0 (a bright color, inclusive)
526         */
527        public static float saturation(final float encoded) {
528                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
529                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
530                if(Math.abs(L - 0.5) > 0.495f) return 0f;
531                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
532                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
533                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
534                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
535                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
536                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
537                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
538                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
539                float x, y, w;
540                if(g < b) {
541                        x = b;
542                        y = g;
543                }
544                else {
545                        x = g;
546                        y = b;
547                }
548                if(r < x) {
549                        w = r;
550                }
551                else {
552                        w = x;
553                        x = r;
554                }
555                return x - Math.min(w, y);
556        }
557
558        /**
559         * Defined as per HSL; normally you only need {@link #channelL(float)} to get accurate lightness for Oklab. You can
560         * also use {@link #oklabLightness(float)}, which is an alias for channelL(). This ranges from 0.0f (black) to 1.0f
561         * (white).
562         *
563         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
564         * @return the lightness of the given color as HSL would calculate it
565         */
566        public static float lightness(final float encoded) {
567                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
568                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
569                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
570                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
571                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
572                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
573                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
574                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
575                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
576                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
577                float x, y, w;
578                if(g < b) {
579                        x = b;
580                        y = g;
581                }
582                else {
583                        x = g;
584                        y = b;
585                }
586                if(r < x) {
587                        w = r;
588                }
589                else {
590                        w = x;
591                        x = r;
592                }
593                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
594                return x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
595        }
596
597        /**
598         * Gets the hue of the given encoded color, as a float from 0f (inclusive, red and approaching orange if increased)
599         * to 1f (exclusive, red and approaching purple if decreased). You can also use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, which
600         * positions the different hues at different values, somewhat, from this, but is more accurate to how Oklab handles
601         * hues.
602         *
603         * @param encoded a color as a packed float that can be obtained by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
604         * @return The hue of the color from 0.0 (red, inclusive) towards orange, then yellow, and
605         * eventually to purple before looping back to almost the same red (1.0, exclusive)
606         */
607        public static float hue(final float encoded) {
608                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
609                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
610                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
611                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
612                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
613                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
614                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
615                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
616                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
617                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
618                float x, y, z, w;
619                if(g < b) {
620                        x = b;
621                        y = g;
622                        z = -1f;
623                        w = 2f / 3f;
624                }
625                else {
626                        x = g;
627                        y = b;
628                        z = 0f;
629                        w = -1f / 3f;
630                }
631                if(r < x) {
632                        z = w;
633                        w = r;
634                }
635                else {
636                        w = x;
637                        x = r;
638                }
639                float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
640                return Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f));
641        }
642
643        /**
644         * The "L" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which is its lightness; ranges from 0.0f to
645         * 1.0f . You can edit the L of a color with {@link #lighten(float, float)} and {@link #darken(float, float)}.
646         *
647         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
648         * @return the L value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
649         */
650        public static float channelL(final float encoded)
651        {
652                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) & 0xff) / 255f;
653        }
654
655        /**
656         * The "A" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the B channel describes the
657         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If A is 0f, the color will be cooler, more green or
658         * blue; if A is 1f, the color will be warmer, from magenta to orange. You can edit the A of a color with
659         * {@link #raiseA(float, float)} and {@link #lowerA(float, float)}.
660         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
661         * @return the A value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
662         */
663        public static float channelA(final float encoded)
664        {
665                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 8 & 0xff)) / 255f;
666        }
667
668        /**
669         * The "B" channel of the given packed float in Oklab format, which when combined with the A channel describes the
670         * hue and saturation of a color; ranges from 0f to 1f . If B is 0f, the color will be more "artificial", more
671         * blue or purple; if B is 1f, the color will be more "natural", from green to yellow to orange. You can edit
672         * the B of a color with {@link #raiseB(float, float)} and {@link #lowerB(float, float)}.
673         * @param encoded a color encoded as a packed float, as by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
674         * @return the B value as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f
675         */
676        public static float channelB(final float encoded)
677        {
678                return ((NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded) >>> 16 & 0xff)) / 255f;
679        }
680
681        /**
682         * Gets a variation on the packed float color basis as another packed float that has its hue, saturation, lightness,
683         * and opacity adjusted by the specified amounts. Note that this edits the color in HSL space, not Oklab! Takes
684         * floats representing the amounts of change to apply to hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity; these can be
685         * between -1f and 1f. Returns a float that can be used as a packed or encoded color with methods like
686         * {@link com.badlogic.gdx.graphics.g2d.Batch#setPackedColor(float)}. The float is likely to be different than the
687         * result of {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)} unless hue, saturation, lightness, and opacity are all 0.
688         * This won't allocate any objects.
689         * <br>
690         * The parameters this takes all specify additive changes for a color component, clamping the final values so they
691         * can't go above 1 or below 0, with an exception for hue, which can rotate around if lower or higher hues would be
692         * used. As an example, if you give this 0.4f for saturation, and the current color has saturation 0.7f, then the
693         * resulting color will have 1f for saturation. If you gave this -0.1f for saturation and the current color again
694         * has saturation 0.7f, then resulting color will have 0.6f for saturation.
695         * <br>
696         * You may want {@link #editOklab(float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float, float)} instead, which
697         * adjusts the L, A, B, and alpha channels directly instead of converting to HSL and back.
698         *
699         * @param basis      a packed float color that will be used as the starting point to make the next color
700         * @param hue        -1f to 1f, the hue change that can be applied to the new float color (not clamped, wraps)
701         * @param saturation -1f to 1f, the saturation change that can be applied to the new float color
702         * @param light      -1f to 1f, the light/brightness change that can be applied to the new float color
703         * @param opacity    -1f to 1f, the opacity/alpha change that can be applied to the new float color
704         * @return a float encoding a variation of basis with the given changes
705         */
706        public static float toEditedFloat(float basis, float hue, float saturation, float light, float opacity) {
707                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(basis);
708                final float L = Math.min(Math.max(light + reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f), 0f), 1f);
709                opacity = Math.min(Math.max(opacity + (decoded >>> 24 & 0xfe) * 0x1.020408p-8f, 0f), 1f);
710                if (L <= 0.001f)
711                        return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((((int) (opacity * 255f) << 24) & 0xFE000000) | 0x808000);
712                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
713                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
714                final float l = cube(L + 0.3963377774f * A + 0.2158037573f * B);
715                final float m = cube(L - 0.1055613458f * A - 0.0638541728f * B);
716                final float s = cube(L - 0.0894841775f * A - 1.2914855480f * B);
717                final float r = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(+4.0767245293f * l - 3.3072168827f * m + 0.2307590544f * s, 0f), 1f));
718                final float g = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-1.2681437731f * l + 2.6093323231f * m - 0.3411344290f * s, 0f), 1f));
719                final float b = reverseGamma(Math.min(Math.max(-0.0041119885f * l - 0.7034763098f * m + 1.7068625689f * s, 0f), 1f));
720                float x, y, z, w;
721                if(g < b) {
722                        x = b;
723                        y = g;
724                        z = -1f;
725                        w = 2f / 3f;
726                }
727                else {
728                        x = g;
729                        y = b;
730                        z = 0f;
731                        w = -1f / 3f;
732                }
733                if(r < x) {
734                        z = w;
735                        w = r;
736                }
737                else {
738                        w = x;
739                        x = r;
740                }
741                final float d = x - Math.min(w, y);
742                final float lum = x * (1f - 0.5f * d / (x + 1e-10f));
743                hue += Math.abs(z + (w - y) / (6f * d + 1e-10f)) + 1f;
744                saturation += (x - lum) / (Math.min(lum, 1f - lum) + 1e-10f);
745                return fromRGBA(FloatColors.hsl2rgb(hue - (int)hue, Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f), lum, opacity));
746        }
747
748        /**
749         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards white by change. While change should be between 0f (return
750         * start as-is) and 1f (return white), start should be a packed color, as from
751         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
752         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
753         * white. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
754         * @see #darken(float, float) the counterpart method that darkens a float color
755         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
756         * @param change how much to go from start toward white, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to white
757         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and white
758         */
759        public static float lighten(final float start, final float change) {
760                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
761                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i + (0xFF - i) * change) & 0xFF) | other);
762        }
763
764        /**
765         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards black by change. While change should be between 0f (return
766         * start as-is) and 1f (return black), start should be a packed color, as from
767         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
768         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
769         * black. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and both chroma of start as-is.
770         * @see #lighten(float, float) the counterpart method that lightens a float color
771         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
772         * @param change how much to go from start toward black, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to black
773         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and black
774         */
775        public static float darken(final float start, final float change) {
776                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), i = s & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFFFF00;
777                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (i * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) | other);
778        }
779
780        /**
781         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a warmer color (orange to magenta) by change. While change
782         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully warmed), start should be a packed color, as from
783         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
784         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to
785         * lerp towards a warmer color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
786         * alpha and L of start as-is.
787         * @see #lowerA(float, float) the counterpart method that cools a float color
788         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
789         * @param change how much to warm start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a warmer result
790         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a warmer color
791         */
792        public static float raiseA(final float start, final float change) {
793                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
794                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p + (0xFF - p) * change) << 8 & 0xFF00) | other);
795        }
796
797        /**
798         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a cooler color (green to blue) by change. While change
799         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully cooled), start should be a packed color, as from
800         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
801         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
802         * towards a cooler color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and
803         * L of start as-is.
804         * @see #raiseA(float, float) the counterpart method that warms a float color
805         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
806         * @param change how much to cool start, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a cooler result
807         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a cooler color
808         */
809        public static float lowerA(final float start, final float change) {
810                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), p = s >>> 8 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFEFF00FF;
811                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (p * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 8 | other);
812        }
813
814        /**
815         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards a "natural" color (between green and orange) by change.
816         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully natural), start should be a packed color, as
817         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
818         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using
819         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards a more natural color. Unlike
820         * {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the alpha and L of start as-is.
821         * @see #lowerB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less natural
822         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
823         * @param change how much to change start to a natural color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more natural result
824         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more natural color
825         */
826        public static float raiseB(final float start, final float change) {
827                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
828                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t + (0xFF - t) * change) << 16 & 0xFF0000) | other);
829        }
830
831        /**
832         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards an "artificial" color (between blue and purple) by change.
833         * While change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully artificial), start should be a packed color, as
834         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary
835         * Colors, and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp
836         * towards a more artificial color. Unlike {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)}, this keeps the
837         * alpha and L of start as-is.
838         * @see #raiseB(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less artificial
839         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
840         * @param change how much to change start to a bolder color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more artificial result
841         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a more artificial color
842         */
843        public static float lowerB(final float start, final float change) {
844                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), t = s >>> 16 & 0xFF, other = s & 0xFE00FFFF;
845                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (t * (1f - change)) & 0xFF) << 16 | other);
846        }
847
848        /**
849         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards that color made opaque by change. While change should be
850         * between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return start with full alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
851         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors, and
852         * is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
853         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
854         * @see #fade(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more translucent
855         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
856         * @param change how much to go from start toward opaque, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to opaque
857         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and its opaque version
858         */
859        public static float blot(final float start, final float change) {
860                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s >>> 24 & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
861                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity + (0xFE - opacity) * change) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
862        }
863
864        /**
865         * Interpolates from the packed float color start towards transparent by change. While change should be between 0
866         * (return start as-is) and 1f (return the color with 0 alpha), start should be a packed color, as from
867         * {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This is a good way to reduce allocations of temporary Colors,
868         * and is a little more efficient and clear than using {@link FloatColors#lerpFloatColors(float, float, float)} to lerp towards
869         * transparent. This won't change the L, A, or B of the color.
870         * @see #blot(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more opaque
871         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
872         * @param change how much to go from start toward transparent, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means closer to transparent
873         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and transparent
874         */
875        public static float fade(final float start, final float change) {
876                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start), opacity = s & 0xFE, other = s & 0x00FFFFFF;
877                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (opacity * (1f - change)) & 0xFE) << 24 | other);
878        }
879
880        /**
881         * Brings the chromatic components of {@code start} closer to grayscale by {@code change} (desaturating them). While
882         * change should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return fully gray), start should be a packed color, as
883         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This only changes A and B; it leaves L and alpha alone, unlike
884         * {@link #lessenChange(float, float)}, which usually changes L.
885         * @see #enrich(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color more saturated
886         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
887         * @param change how much to change start to a desaturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a less saturated result
888         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a desaturated color
889         */
890        public static float dullen(final float start, final float change) {
891                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
892                return oklab((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
893                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
894                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f - change) + 0.5f,
895                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
896        }
897
898        /**
899         * Pushes the chromatic components of {@code start} away from grayscale by change (saturating them). While change
900         * should be between 0f (return start as-is) and 1f (return maximally saturated), start should be a packed color, as
901         * from {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}. This changes only A and B. Higher values for {@code change} can
902         * force the color out of the gamut, which this corrects using {@link #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float)}.
903         * The alpha never changes.
904         * @see #dullen(float, float) the counterpart method that makes a float color less saturated
905         * @param start the starting color as a packed float
906         * @param change how much to change start to a saturated color, as a float between 0 and 1; higher means a more saturated result
907         * @return a packed float that represents a color between start and a saturated color
908         */
909        public static float enrich(final float start, final float change) {
910                final int s = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(start);
911                return limitToGamut((s & 0xFF) / 255f,
912                                ((s >>> 8 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
913                                ((s >>> 16 & 0xFF) / 255f - 0.5f) * (1f + change) + 0.5f,
914                                (s >>> 25) / 127f);
915        }
916
917        /**
918         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast with,
919         * gets a packed float Oklab color with roughly inverted L but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B
920         * are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white or black). This won't ever produce black or other very
921         * dark colors, and also has a gap in the range it produces for L values between 0.5 and 0.55. That allows
922         * most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on a background of
923         * {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa. This will leave the L unchanged if the chromatic channels of the
924         * contrastingColor and those of the mainColor are already very different. This has nothing to do with the contrast
925         * channel of the tweak in ColorfulBatch; where that part of the tweak can make too-similar lightness values further
926         * apart by just a little, this makes a modification on {@code mainColor} to maximize its lightness difference from
927         * {@code contrastingColor} without losing its other qualities.
928         * @param mainColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
929         *                     this is the color that will be adjusted
930         * @param contrastingColor a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)};
931         *                            the adjusted mainColor will contrast with this
932         * @return a different Oklab packed float color, based on mainColor but with potentially very different lightness
933         */
934        public static float inverseLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
935        {
936                final int bits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor),
937                                contrastBits = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor),
938                                L = (bits & 0xff),
939                                A = (bits >>> 8 & 0xff),
940                                B = (bits >>> 16 & 0xff),
941                                cL = (contrastBits & 0xff),
942                                cA = (contrastBits >>> 8 & 0xff),
943                                cB = (contrastBits >>> 16 & 0xff);
944                if((A - cA) * (A - cA) + (B - cB) * (B - cB) >= 0x10000)
945                        return mainColor;
946                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((bits & 0xFEFFFF00) | (int) (cL < 128 ? L * 0.45f + 140 : 127 - L * 0.45f));
947        }
948
949        /**
950         * Given a packed float Oklab color {@code mainColor} and another Oklab color that it should be made to contrast
951         * with, gets a packed float Oklab color with L that should be quite different from {@code contrastingColor}'s L,
952         * but the same chromatic channels and opacity (A and B are likely to be clamped if the result gets close to white
953         * or black). This allows most of the colors this method produces to contrast well as a foreground when displayed on
954         * a background of {@code contrastingColor}, or vice versa.
955         * <br>
956         * This is similar to {@link #inverseLightness(float, float)}, but is considerably simpler, and this method will
957         * change the lightness of mainColor when the two given colors have close lightness but distant chroma. Because it
958         * averages the original L of mainColor with the modified one, this tends to not produce harsh color changes.
959         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color; this is the color that will be adjusted
960         * @param contrastingColor a packed Oklab float color; the adjusted mainColor will contrast with the L of this
961         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, based on mainColor but typically with different lightness
962         */
963        public static float differentiateLightness(final float mainColor, final float contrastingColor)
964        {
965                final int main = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor), contrast = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(contrastingColor);
966                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((main & 0xFEFFFF00) | (contrast + 128 & 0xFF) + (main & 0xFF) >>> 1));
967        }
968
969        /**
970         * Pretty simple; adds 0.5 to the given color's L and wraps it around if it would go above 1.0, then averages that
971         * with the original L. This means light colors become darker, and dark colors become lighter, with almost all
972         * results in the middle-range of possible lightness.
973         * @param mainColor a packed Oklab float color
974         * @return a different packed Oklab float color, with its L channel changed and limited to the correct gamut
975         */
976        public static float offsetLightness(final float mainColor) {
977                final int oklab = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(mainColor);
978                return limitToGamut(NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((oklab & 0xFEFFFF00) | (oklab + 128 & 0xFF) + (oklab & 0xFF) >>> 1));
979        }
980
981        /**
982         * Makes the additive Oklab color stored in {@code color} cause less of a change when used as a tint, as if it were
983         * mixed with neutral gray. When {@code fraction} is 1.0, this returns color unchanged; when fraction is 0.0, it
984         * returns {@link Palette#GRAY}, and when it is in-between 0.0 and 1.0 it returns something between the two. This is
985         * meant for things like area of effect abilities that make smaller color changes toward their periphery.
986         * @param color a color that should have its tinting effect potentially weakened
987         * @param fraction how much of {@code color} should be kept, from 0.0 to 1.0
988         * @return an Oklab float color between gray and {@code color}
989         */
990        public static float lessenChange(final float color, float fraction) {
991                final int e = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color),
992                                sL = 0x80, sA = 0x80, sB = 0x80, sAlpha = 0xFE,
993                                eL = (e & 0xFF), eA = (e >>> 8) & 0xFF, eB = (e >>> 16) & 0xFF, eAlpha = e >>> 24 & 0xFE;
994                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(((int) (sL + fraction * (eL - sL)) & 0xFF)
995                                | (((int) (sA + fraction * (eA - sA)) & 0xFF) << 8)
996                                | (((int) (sB + fraction * (eB - sB)) & 0xFF) << 16)
997                                | (((int) (sAlpha + fraction * (eAlpha - sAlpha)) & 0xFE) << 24));
998        }
999
1000        /**
1001         * Makes a quasi-randomly-edited variant on the given {@code color}, allowing typically a small amount of
1002         * {@code variance} (such as 0.05 to 0.25) between the given color and what this can return. The {@code seed} should
1003         * be different each time this is called, and can be obtained from a random number generator to make the colors more
1004         * random, or can be incremented on each call. If the seed is only incremented or decremented, then this shouldn't
1005         * produce two similar colors in a row unless variance is very small. The variance affects the L, A, and B of the
1006         * generated color, and each of those channels can go up or down by the given variance as long as the total distance
1007         * isn't greater than the variance (this considers A and B extra-wide, going from -1 to 1, while L goes from 0 to 1,
1008         * but only internally for measuring distance).
1009         * @param color a packed float color, as produced by {@link #oklab(float, float, float, float)}
1010         * @param seed a long seed that should be different on each call; should not be 0
1011         * @param variance max amount of difference between the given color and the generated color; always less than 1
1012         * @return a generated packed float color that should be at least somewhat different from {@code color}
1013         */
1014        public static float randomEdit(final float color, long seed, final float variance) {
1015                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(color);
1016                final float L = reverseLight((decoded & 0xff) / 255f);
1017                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1018                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1019                final float limit = variance * variance;
1020                float dist, x, y, z;
1021                for (int j = 0; j < 50; j++) {
1022                        x = (((seed * 0xD1B54A32D192ED03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1023                        y = (((seed * 0xABC98388FB8FAC03L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1024                        z = (((seed * 0x8CB92BA72F3D8DD7L >>> 41) - 0x7FFFFFp-1f) * 0x1p-22f) * variance;
1025                        seed += 0x9E3779B97F4A7C15L;
1026                        dist = x * x + y * y + z * z;
1027                        if(dist <= limit && inGamut(x += L, y = (A + y) * 0.5f + 0.5f, z = (B + z) * 0.5f + 0.5f))
1028                                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat((decoded & 0xFE000000) | ((int)(z * 255.5f) << 16 & 0xFF0000)
1029                                        | ((int)(y * 255.5f) << 8 & 0xFF00) | (int)(x * 255.5f));
1030                }
1031                return color;
1032        }
1033
1034        private static final byte[] GAMUT_DATA = Gamut.GAMUT_DATA;
1035
1036        /**
1037         * Given a 1D int index between 0 and 65535 (both inclusive), this treats the 1D index as two parts (lightness and
1038         * hue angle, both from 0 to 255) and gets the distance from grayscale to the edge of the gamut at that lightness
1039         * and hue. The index can be constructed from a lightness value {@code L} from 0 to 255, and a hue value {@code H}
1040         * from 0 to 255 with: {@code (L << 8 | H)} or the simpler equivalent {@code (L * 256 + H)}. These assume L and H
1041         * have been limited to the 0 to 255 range already. This does not bounds-check index. Because hue is not typically
1042         * measured between 0 and 255, getting that value is a bit different; you can use
1043         * {@link TrigTools#atan2_(float, float)} (with an Oklab color's B for y, then its A for x) and multiply it by 256
1044         * to get H.
1045         * <br>
1046         * The distance this returns is a byte between 0 and 82 (both inclusive), as the Euclidean distance from the center
1047         * grayscale value at the lightness in the index, to the edge of the gamut at the same lightness, along the hue in
1048         * the index. This is measured in a space from -1 to 1 for both A and B, with the 0 in the center meaning grayscale,
1049         * and multiplied by 256 to get a meaningful byte value. To return to the A and B values Oklab uses here, you would
1050         * need to use some trigonometry on the hue (if it's in the 0 to 1 range, you can call
1051         * {@link TrigTools#cos_(float)} on the hue to almost get A, and {@link TrigTools#sin_(float)} to almost get B),
1052         * then multiply each of those by the distance, divide each by 256.0, and add 0.5.
1053         * <br>
1054         * Only intended for the narrow cases where external code needs read-only access to the internal Oklab gamut data.
1055         * The gamut data is quite large (the Oklab ColorTools file is 236 KB at the time of writing, while the IPT_HQ
1056         * ColorTools file is just 56 KB, with the main difference being the sizable exact gamut), so it's better to have
1057         * direct read access to it without being able to accidentally rewrite it.
1058         * @param index must be between 0 and 65535; the upper 8 bits are lightness and the lower 8 are hue angle.
1059         * @return a byte (always between 0 and 82, inclusive) representing the Euclidean distance between a grayscale value and the most saturated value possible, using the above measurements
1060         */
1061        public static byte getRawGamutValue(int index){
1062                return GAMUT_DATA[index];
1063        }
1064
1065        /**
1066         * Returns true if the given packed float color, as Oklab, is valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1067         * @param packed a packed float color as Oklab
1068         * @return true if the given packed float color can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1069         */
1070        public static boolean inGamut(final float packed)
1071        {
1072                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1073                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1074                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127f) / 255f;
1075                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[(decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1076                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1077        }
1078
1079        /**
1080         * Returns true if the given Oklab values are valid to convert losslessly back to RGBA.
1081         * @param L lightness channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1082         * @param A green-to-red chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1083         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic channel, as a float from 0 to 1
1084         * @return true if the given Oklab channels can be converted back and forth to RGBA
1085         */
1086        public static boolean inGamut(float L, float A, float B)
1087        {
1088                A = ((int) (A * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1089                B = ((int) (B * 255) - 127f) / 255f;
1090                final float g = GAMUT_DATA[((int) (L * 255) & 0xFF) << 8 | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1091                return g * g * 0x1p-18 + 0x1p-14 >= (A * A + B * B);
1092
1093                ////This was the old code for this inGamut(), which was subtly different from the other inGamut() when called
1094                /// on a packed float. The packed floats can go ever-so-slightly towards or away from the edge.
1095//              A = (A - 0.5f);
1096//              B = (B - 0.5f);
1097//              final byte g = GAMUT_DATA[((int)(L * 255.999f) << 8) | (int)(256f * TrigTools.atan2_(B, A))];
1098//              return g * g * 0x1p-16 >= (A * A + B * B);
1099
1100        }
1101
1102        /**
1103         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1104         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1105         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1106         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; does not need to be in-gamut
1107         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1108         * @see #limitToGamut(float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation for out-of-gamut colors.
1109         */
