1110        public static float maximizeSaturation(final float packed) {
1111                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1112                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1113                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1114                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1115                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1116                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];// * 0.5f;
1117                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1118                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1119                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1120                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1121        }
1122        /**
1123         * Gets the color with the same L as the Oklab color stored in the given packed float, but the furthest A
1124         * B from gray possible for that lightness while keeping the same hue as the given color. This is very
1125         * similar to calling {@link #enrich(float, float)} with a very large {@code change} value.
1126         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1127         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1128         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1129         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1130         * @return the color that is as far from grayscale as this can get while keeping the L and hue of packed
1131         * @see #limitToGamut(float, float, float, float) You can use limitToGamut() if you only want max saturation
1132         * for out-of-gamut colors.
1133         */
1134        public static float maximizeSaturation(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1135                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1136                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1137                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f) - 0.5f;
1138                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1139                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1140                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1141                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];// * 0.5f;
1142                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1143                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1144                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1145                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1146                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1147        }
1148
1149        /**
1150         * Gets the hue of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands hue rather than how HSL does.
1151         * This is different from {@link #hue(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1152         * and 1 (exclusive).
1153         *
1154         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1155         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (exclusive) that represents hue in the Oklab color space
1156         */
1157        public static float oklabHue(final float packed) {
1158                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1159                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1160                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1161                return TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1162        }
1163
1164        /**
1165         * Gets the saturation of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands saturation rather than how HSL does.
1166         * Saturation here is a fraction of the chroma limit (see {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}) for a given hue and
1167         * lightness, and is between 0 and 1 almost all the time. Some very bright or dark colors may have their lightness
1168         * adjusted in conflicting ways at different stages of processing, which can yield saturation greater than 1 in
1169         * those cases. 1.2 is probably the practical maximum for rare cases. In any other case, this gives a float between
1170         * 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive).
1171         *
1172         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1173         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and usually 1 (inclusive) that represents saturation in the Oklab color space
1174         */
1175        public static float oklabSaturation(final float packed) {
1176                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1177                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1178                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1179                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1180                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1181                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] + 1.5f;
1182                return dist == 3.5f ? 0f : (A * A + B * B) * 4f / (dist * dist);
1183        }
1184        /**
1185         * Gets the lightness of the given Oklab float color, but as Oklab understands lightness rather than how HSL does.
1186         * This is different from {@link #lightness(float)}, which uses HSL. This gives a float between 0 (inclusive)
1187         * and 1 (inclusive).
1188         * <br>
1189         * This is the same as {@link #channelL(float)}.
1190         *
1191         * @param packed a packed Oklab float color
1192         * @return a float between 0 (inclusive) and 1 (inclusive) that represents lightness in the Oklab color space
1193         */
1194        public static float oklabLightness(final float packed){
1195                return (NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed) & 0xff) / 255f;
1196        }
1197
1198        /**
1199         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, saturation, lightness, and alpha like a normal HSL(A) color
1200         * but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This is more efficient than
1201         * {@link #floatGetHSL(float, float, float, float)}, but for colors with less than 0.5f lightness, it can be very
1202         * unpredictable in how it handles saturation. Most colors between 0.5 and 0.75 hue that also have less than 0.5
1203         * lightness are extremely desaturated and close to gray, regardless of what you give for saturation, and these
1204         * colors suddenly jump to very saturated around 0.75 hue and higher. To avoid this issue, you may prefer using
1205         * {@link #oklabByHCL(float, float, float, float)}, which takes an absolute chroma as opposed to the saturation here
1206         * (which is a fraction of the maximum chroma).
1207         * <br>
1208         * Note that this takes a different value for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just
1209         * like its {@code saturation} and the method {@link #saturation(float)}, and {@code lightness} and the method
1210         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1211         * {@link #channelL(float)}, but the saturation here refers to what fraction the chroma should be of the maximum
1212         * chroma for the given hue and lightness. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)}, {@link #oklabSaturation(float)},
1213         * and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, saturation, and lightness values from an existing color that
1214         * this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1215         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1216         * @param saturation will be clamped between 0 and 1
1217         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1218         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1219         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, saturation, and lightness
1220         */
1221        public static float oklabByHSL(float hue, float saturation, float lightness, float alpha) {
1222                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1223                saturation = Math.min(Math.max(saturation, 0f), 1f);
1224                hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
1225                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1226                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1227                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx] * saturation * 0.5f;
1228                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1229                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1230                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1231                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1232                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1233        }
1234
1235        /**
1236         * A different way to specify an Oklab color, using hue, chroma, lightness, and alpha something like a normal HSL(A)
1237         * color but calculating them directly in the Oklab color space. This has you specify the desired chroma directly,
1238         * as obtainable with {@link #chroma(float)}, rather than the saturation, which is a fraction of the maximum chroma
1239         * (saturation is what {@link #oklabByHSL(float, float, float, float)} uses). Note that this takes a different value
1240         * for its {@code hue} that the method {@link #hue(float)} produces, just like {@code lightness} and the method
1241         * {@link #lightness(float)}. The hue is just distributed differently, and the lightness should be equivalent to
1242         * {@link #channelL(float)}. If you use this to get two colors with the same chroma and lightness, but different
1243         * hue, then the resulting colors should have similar colorfulness unless one or both chroma values exceeded the
1244         * gamut limit (you can get this limit with {@link #chromaLimit(float, float)}). If a chroma value given is greater
1245         * than the chroma limit, this clamps chroma to that limit. You can use {@link #oklabHue(float)},
1246         * {@link #chroma(float)}, and {@link #oklabLightness(float)} to get the hue, chroma, and lightness values from an
1247         * existing color that this will understand ({@link #alpha(float)} too).
1248         * @param hue between 0 and 1, usually, but this will automatically wrap if too high or too low
1249         * @param chroma will be clamped between 0 and the maximum chroma possible for the given hue and lightness
1250         * @param lightness will be clamped between 0 and 1
1251         * @param alpha will be clamped between 0 and 1
1252         * @return a packed Oklab float color that tries to match the requested hue, chroma, and lightness
1253         */
1254        public static float oklabByHCL(float hue, float chroma, float lightness, float alpha) {
1255                lightness = Math.min(Math.max(lightness, 0f), 1f);
1256                chroma = Math.max(chroma, 0f);
1257                hue -= MathUtils.floor(hue);
1258                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1259                final int idx = (int) (lightness * 255.999f) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1260                final float dist = Math.min(chroma * 127.5f, GAMUT_DATA[idx]);// * 0.5f);
1261                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1262                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1263                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 16 |
1264                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 127.5f) << 8 |
1265                                                (int) (lightness * 255.999f));
1266        }
1267
1268        /**
1269         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1270         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1271         * @param packed a packed float color in Oklab format; often this color is not in-gamut
1272         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1273         * @see #inGamut(float) You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1274         */
1275        public static float limitToGamut(final float packed) {
1276                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(packed);
1277                final float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1278                final float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f);
1279                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1280                final int idx = (decoded & 0xff) << 8 | (int) (256f * hue);
1281                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];// * 0.5f;
1282                if (dist * dist * 0.25f >= (A * A + B * B))
1283                        return packed;
1284                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1285                                (decoded & 0xFE0000FF) |
1286                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1287                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16);
1288        }
1289
1290        /**
1291         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1292         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is. This always produces
1293         * an opaque color.
1294         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1295         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1296         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1297         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1298         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1299         */
1300        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B) {
1301                return limitToGamut(L, A, B, 1f);
1302        }
1303        /**
1304         * Checks whether the given Oklab color is in-gamut; if it isn't in-gamut, brings the color just inside
1305         * the gamut at the same lightness, or if it is already in-gamut, returns the color as-is.
1306         * @param L lightness component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1307         * @param A green-to-red chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1308         * @param B blue-to-yellow chromatic component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1309         * @param alpha alpha component; will be clamped between 0 and 1 if it isn't already
1310         * @return the first color this finds that is in-gamut, as if it was moving toward a grayscale color with the same L
1311         * @see #inGamut(float, float, float)  You can use inGamut() if you just want to check whether a color is in-gamut.
1312         */
1313        public static float limitToGamut(float L, float A, float B, float alpha) {
1314                L = Math.min(Math.max(L, 0f), 1f);
1315                A = Math.min(Math.max(A, 0f), 1f);
1316                B = Math.min(Math.max(B, 0f), 1f);
1317                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha, 0f), 1f);
1318                final float A2 = (A - 0.5f);
1319                final float B2 = (B - 0.5f);
1320                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B2, A2);
1321                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1322                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];// * 0.5f;
1323                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-18f + 0x1p-14f >= (A2 * A2 + B2 * B2))
1324                        return oklab(L, A, B, alpha);
1325                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1326                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1327                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1328                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1329                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1330        }
1331
1332        /**
1333         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by adding the corresponding "add"
1334         * parameter and then clamping. This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1335         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged. This clamps the
1336         * resulting color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1337         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1338         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1339         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1340         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1341         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1342         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1343         */
1344        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha) {
1345                return editOklab(encoded, addL, addA, addB, addAlpha, 1f, 1f, 1f, 1f);
1346        }
1347        /**
1348         * Given a packed float Oklab color, this edits its L, A, B, and alpha channels by first multiplying each channel by
1349         * the corresponding "mul" parameter and then adding the corresponding "add" parameter, before clamping. This means
1350         * the lightness value {@code L} is multiplied by {@code mulL}, then has {@code addL} added, and then is clamped to
1351         * the normal range for L (0 to 1). This returns a different float value (of course, the given float can't be edited
1352         * in-place). You can give a value of 0 for any "add" parameter you want to stay unchanged, or a value of 1 for any
1353         * "mul" parameter that shouldn't change. Note that this manipulates A and B in the -0.5 to 0.5 range, so if you
1354         * multiply by a small number like {@code 0.25f}, then this will produce a less-saturated color, and if you multiply
1355         * by a larger number like {@code 4f}, then you will get a much more-saturated color. This clamps the resulting
1356         * color to remain in-gamut, so it should be safe to convert it back to RGBA.
1357         * @param encoded a packed float Oklab color
1358         * @param addL how much to add to the L channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1359         * @param addA how much to add to the A channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1360         * @param addB how much to add to the B channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1361         * @param addAlpha how much to add to the alpha channel; typically in the -1 to 1 range
1362         * @param mulL how much to multiply the L channel by; should be non-negative
1363         * @param mulA how much to multiply the A channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1364         * @param mulB how much to multiply the B channel by; usually non-negative (not always)
1365         * @param mulAlpha how much to multiply the alpha channel by; should be non-negative
1366         * @return a packed float Oklab color with the requested edits applied to {@code encoded}
1367         */
1368        public static float editOklab(float encoded, float addL, float addA, float addB, float addAlpha,
1369                                                                  float mulL, float mulA, float mulB, float mulAlpha) {
1370                final int decoded = NumberUtils.floatToRawIntBits(encoded);
1371                float L = (decoded & 0xff) / 255f;
1372                float A = ((decoded >>> 8 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1373                float B = ((decoded >>> 16 & 0xff) - 127.5f) / 127.5f;
1374                float alpha = (decoded >>> 25) / 127f;
1375
1376                L = Math.min(Math.max(L * mulL + addL, 0f), 1f);
1377                A = Math.min(Math.max(A * mulA + addA * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1378                B = Math.min(Math.max(B * mulB + addB * 2f, -1f), 1f) * 0.5f;
1379                alpha = Math.min(Math.max(alpha * mulAlpha + addAlpha, 0f), 1f);
1380                final float hue = TrigTools.atan2_(B, A);
1381                final int idx = (int) (L * 255.999f) << 8 | (int)(256f * hue);
1382                final float dist = GAMUT_DATA[idx];// * 0.5f;
1383                if(dist * dist * 0x1p-18f >= (A * A + B * B))
1384                        return oklab(L, A + 0.5f, B + 0.5f, alpha);
1385                return NumberUtils.intBitsToFloat(
1386                                (int) (alpha * 127.999f) << 25 |
1387                                                (int) (TrigTools.sin_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 16 |
1388                                                (int) (TrigTools.cos_(hue) * dist + 128f) << 8 |
1389                                                (int) (L * 255.999f));
1390        }
1391
1392        /**
1393         * Produces a random packed float color that is always in-gamut (and opaque) and should be uniformly distributed.
1394         * @param random a Random object (preferably a subclass of Random, like {@link com.badlogic.gdx.math.RandomXS128})
1395         * @return a packed float color that is always in-gamut
1396         */
1397        public static float randomColor(Random random) {
1398                float L = random.nextFloat();
1399                float A = random.nextFloat();
1400                float B = random.nextFloat();
1401                while (!inGamut(L, A, B)) {
1402                        L = random.nextFloat();
1403                        A = random.nextFloat();
1404                        B = random.nextFloat();
1405                }
1406                return oklab(L, A, B, 1f);
1407        }
1408}
